Mizraḥi taught publically until 1475 when he became the most famous religious authority in the entire Ottoman Empire and questions on <i>halakhah</i> were addressed to him from all over. He was well respected as an halakhic decision maker, <i>posek</i>, in Turkey by his contemporaries and those who came after him.<br>In addition to teaching and heading the yeshivah he also wrote commentaries to religious as well as scientific works. He collected money to help absorb the exiles of Spain and Portugal. He respected the knowledge of the exiles, but he refused to allow them to bring in their customs foreign to Turkey. He helped teach the Karaites secular subjects as well as Oral Law, but he refused to allow Karaites to marry Rabbanites.<br>Mizraḥi had a very clear halakhic style. He presented the fundamental principles and then he raised possible objections to them and then he examined and clarified each one. His responsa were thus considered authoritative even by those who opposed his views.<br>He is known to have had a very sad, poor life, with much family misfortune, but that did not hamper his work. His most famous halakhic accomplishment was his super-commentary to Rashi published in Venice in 1527. He discussed every word of Rashi and often disagreed with him, yet he defended Rashi against Naḥmanides. The combined works were studied by most biblical rabbinical commentators from the sixteenth century onward.<br>Jacob Haberman, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 12, pp. 182-84</i> You may rely upon this (lenient decision of the <i>Yeish Omrim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yeish Omrim</i>, <span class="rtl">יש אומרים</span>; When this expression was used in the Shulḥan Arukh it referred to a source which was transmitted anonymously. The name of the authority was not transmitted along with the source. But in tractate <i>Horayot</i>, <span class="rtl">הוריות</span>, of the Babylonian Talmud which is concerned with what is to be done in cases of an erroneous decision by the court, the reference <i>Yeish Omrim</i> did refer to a specific person. In <i>Horayot</i> 13b, an incident was related where Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Natan tried to embarrass Rabbi Judah ha-Nasi to the extent that he would be deposed. Rabbi Judah ha-Nasi found out about the conspiracy and the decision was made that Rabbi Meir was to be punished by referring to him from that point on as <i>Aḥeirim</i>, <span class="rtl">אחרים</span>, "others", and not using his name. Rabbi Natan's name was also to be concealed and his sayings were thereafter introduced by the expression <i>Yeish Omrim</i>, <span class="rtl">יש אומרים</span>, "there are those who say".<br>This is not the reference, though, made in the Shulḥan Arukh, (Alexander Guttmann).</i>) with respect to a youth who is thin and is not strong enough to fast, (<span dir="ltr">תרומת הדשן סימן קנ״ה</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i>, chapter 155; <span class="rtl">־־־־</span>; see footnote 96.</i> And in every instance that we train him (the child) in the restriction of the laws of eating we (also) train him with respect to the restriction of washing and annointing, (<span dir="ltr">טור</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <span class="rtl">טור</span>; see footnote 23.</i></small><br>A twelve year and one day old girl and a thirteen year and one day old boy who show the signs of puberty (two hairs), behold they are considered adults for every commandment and they complete the fast according to the Torah. But if they do not show the signs of puberty they are still considered children and they do not complete the fast except because of the ruling of the rabbis.<br><small><i>Hagah</i>: Even if he (the child) is tender and thin (meaning, he is of age but does not show the signs of puberty), he has to complete the fast because the hairs of puberty might have fallen off,<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">This is one of the few instances where Isserles, in his disagreement with Caro's decision, was more strict. He usually tended toward leniency but here Isserles had decided that a twelve year and one day old girl and a thirteen year and one day old boy must fast regardless of whether or not they have started to grow pubic hairs. Puberty along with age in Judaism indicated adulthood and the religious responsibilities that it brought. Isserles changed this ruling and made it more strict deciding that age alone would mark adulthood and its religious obligations even for one who reaches puberty later than most normally do. The reason Isserles gave is that the person might actually have grown some pubic hairs but, because of their fragility, they might have fallen off before they could be noticed. Therefore, age determined when one was obligated to begin a full fast on Yom Kippur.</i> (<span dir="ltr">תרומת הדשן סי‘ קנ״ה</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i>, <span class="rtl">תרומת הדשן</span>, chapter 155; see footnote 96.</i></small><br>A boy who is less than nine years old, one does not make him fast on Yom Kippur so he would not be endangered.<br><small><i>Hagah</i> : Even if he wants to be strict on himself (and fast), we prevent him (from doing so), (<span dir="ltr">כל בו</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kol Bo</i>, <span class="rtl">כל בר</span>; see footnote 34.</i></small>

Siman 617

<b>“The laws concerning a pregnant woman, and one who nurses a child, and giving birth on Yom Kippur” - Containing four paragraphs.</b><br>Pregnant and nursing women fast completely on Yom Kippur.
A pregnant woman who smells (food and her face changes even though she did not say “I need it”) we whisper in her ear that it is Yom Kippur and if she quiets down when this is mentioned it is fine, but if not, then we feed her (until) she is satisfied.
Every person who smells food and his face changes (its color) and he is in danger if they do not give him from it (the food which he smells), we feed him from it (the food).
A woman who gives birth must not fast at all within three days (of giving birth). From three until seven (days), if she says, “I have to eat,” feed her. From now on (after seven days), behold she is like every other person. And we do not count these as twenty-four hour days, for example if she gives birth in the evening of the seventh of Tishrei, we do not feed her on Yom Kippur (the tenth day of Tishrei) if she does not say, “I need it (food),” even though the three days were not completed for her until the evening of Yom Kippur, since (Yom Kippur) begins the fourth day after her giving birth, this is called after three days.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Yom Kippur in this example is actually the fourth day but the term "day" here is not to be understood as precisely a twenty-four hour day. In other words, according to a strict counting of twenty-four hours, she should be given food on the evening of the tenth of Tishrei which is Yom Kippur, but if the woman does not feel that she needs the food at this time after giving birth she is considered legally already in her fourth day after giving birth where the law states that she may fast unless she feels she must eat. She may not observe the fast up to seven days after giving birth, but after that time has elapsed, she must fast as every other person does. It was felt that she was out of physical danger by this time unless complications arose.</i> (Yom Kippur here is counted as the fourth day after her giving birth.)

Siman 618

<b>“The law concerning one who is sick on Yom Kippur” - Containing ten paragraphs.</b><br>A sick person who needs to eat, if there is an expert doctor there, even if he is a non-Jew,<sup class="footnote-marker">125a</sup><i class="footnote">The following is a comment given by <i>Magen Avraham</i>, (see footnote 33.): 618:1 - "Even if he is a Gentile": The Rosh, <span class="rtl">הרא״ש</span>, (see footnote 62) wrote in the name of Riba, <span class="rtl">ריב״א</span>, (Riba are the initials of <i>R</i>abbi <i>I</i>saac <i>B</i>en <i>A</i>sher who was also known as Isaac ben Asher ha-Levi. He lived in the second half of the eleventh and the first half of the twelfth century. He was a talmudist of Speyer and the first of the German tosafists. He was a pupil of Rashi. He was well respected by his contemporaries and was consulted on many halakhic questions. His death came as the result of choosing to fast on Yom Kippur even though he was warned that if he did so he would die. He compiled tosafot to most of the tractates of the Talmud and his halakhic decisions are quoted in later halakhic works; Shlomoh Zalman Havlin, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 9, pp. 16-17), that a Gentile or a woman are believed to effectively contradict a Jew (in this situation).</i> who says<sup class="footnote-marker">125b</sup><i class="footnote">The following comment is given by <i>Magen Avraham</i>, (see footnote 33.): 618:2 - "Who says": Even if he does not say that he will endanger himself, only that he says that it is possible that the illness will worsen on him, we give him (food) since we fear that perhaps he will endanger himself (by not eating), (<i>Bayit Ḥadash</i>, <span class="rtl">ב״ח</span>, see footnote 20b.; <i>Maharash</i>, <span class="rtl">מהר״ש</span>, <i>M</i>orenu <i>h</i>a-Rav <i>R</i>abenu <i>S</i>himshon of Chinon (France); <i>Levush</i>, <span class="rtl">לבוש</span>, see footnote 20a., and <i>Maharil</i>, <span class="rtl">מהרי״ל</span>, see footnote 8.).</i> that if this person is not fed it is possible that the illness will worsen on him, needless to say if he might be in mortal danger, they feed him on the doctor’s orders. If the sick person says that he does not need (the food) we still listen to the doctor, but if the sick person says, “I need (the nourishment),” even if one hundred doctors say that he does not need (the nourishment) we listen to the ill person.
One doctor says that the sick person needs (food) and another doctor says that he does not need (the food), we feed him (the sick person).<br><small><i>Hagah</i>: The same holds true if two (doctors) disagree with two others even if some of them are better experts than the others (you listen to those who say the patient should eat even if they are the inferior doctors who say this) and so it seems to me (to be the correct decision).</small>
If the sick person and one doctor with him say that he (the sick person) does not need (food), and another doctor says he does need (food), or if the sick person says nothing and one doctor says he needs (food) and two say he does not need (the nourishment), we do not feed him.
If two (doctors) say that he (the sick person) needs (food) and even if one hundred (doctors) say that he does not need (food) even if the sick person agrees with them (who say) he does not need (the food) we feed him since two say that he does need (the food).<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">According to Judaism, two witnesses in any situation are legally just as weighty as one-hundred witnesses, and therefore two witnesses decide the issue as is the case in this instance. In this situation when two say yes, feed him and one hundred say no, do not feed him, the one hundred are legally considered the same as the two. Two against two in this case decides the issue for leniency in that the man should be fed so as not to endanger the health of the sick man. (See <i>B</i>. <i>Yoma</i> 83a.).</i><br><small><i>Hagah</i>: The same holds true (if the sick person and one doctor with him say he needs (the food) even though one hundred doctors say he does not need (the food) we feed him.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><i>ibid</i>., for the same reason when the sick person himself wants the food and counts as the two against the one hundred who are legally considered as two, and two decides the issue to feed the man.</i> (<span dir="ltr">טור</span>)<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <span class="rtl">טור</span>; see footnote 23.</i>), and we are not afraid that the sick person says that he needs (food) because he believes this doctor who says that he needs (the nourishment),<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">In matters of sickness, the statement of the sick person is taken as a sincere and honest statement and not merely as the echo of the doctor's words who the sick person probably respects. Therefore the sick person's word counts as heavily as the doctor's when the man asks to be fed on Yom Kippur. (See <i>B</i>. <i>Yoma</i>, <i>loc</i>. <i>cit</i>.).</i> (<span dir="ltr">ב״י בשם מהרי״א</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i> in the name of Moreiynu ha-Rav Rabbi Israel Isserlein, <span class="rtl">ב״י בשם מהרי״א</span>.<br>For the <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <span class="rtl">בית יוסף</span>; see footnote 20.<br>For Israel Isserlein, <span class="rtl">מהרי״א</span>, see the footnote on <i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i>, footnote 96.</i></small>
If the sick person says that he does not need (the food) and the doctor is doubtful, (whether he definitely needs food or not) we feed him, but if the doctor says that he does not need (food) and the sick person says, “I do not know (whether I need it or not),” we do not feed him.
If the doctor says that he is not familiar with the disease, behold he is considered the same as a layman (a non-professional) and his stated opinion does not raise or lower (does not mean anything).<br><small><i>Hagah</i>: However if he (the sick person) becomes very weak so that he appears to the majority of people with him that he is in danger, if he will not eat, we feed him, (<span dir="ltr">א״ז הארוך</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Issur ve-Hetter he-Arokh</i> was published in Ferrara in 1555. Its authorship has been attributed to Jonah ben Abraham Gerondi. It contains laws on forbidden foods which is the meaning of the title, but it also has laws which are connected with the duty of saving lives.<br>The term <i>issur ve-hetter</i> designates all halakhic rulings on forbidden foods and topics related to that. From the second half of the twelfth century onward it came to specify a literary genre dealing with the subject of forbidden foods. Many books dealing with the subject were produced. As Jews moved and settled in Germany, different customs arose which had not been dealt with before and this produced a need, especially relating to food, as to what was and what was not permitted to Jews.<br>Many of the <i>issur ve-hetter</i> books are anonymous and many glosses and notes have been added to the original texts to make them relevant to new customs. Some of the best known works in this category are: <i>Sefer ha-She'arim</i> or <i>Sha'arei Dura</i>, called "<i>Issur ve-Hetter</i>" by Isaac b. Meir of Dueren; thirty-six <i>She'arim</i> on laws of <i>issur ve-hetter</i> by Israel Isserlein (see footnote 96) along with his glosses to <i>Sha'arei Dura</i>; the laws of <i>issur ve-hetter</i> at the end of <i>Minhagei Maharil</i> (see footnote 8) which is an abridgment of the <i>Sha'arei Dura</i> as is the <i>Torat Ḥattat</i> by Moses Isserles, and the most well known, the <i>Issur ve-Hetter he-Arokh</i>.<br>Jonah Gerondi was born around 1200 and died in 1263. He was a Spanish rabbi, author and moralist. He studied in France where he learned from his teacher Solomon b. Abraham of Montpellier who had an intense hatred for the philosophical works of Maimonides. He helped burn the books of Maimonides but repented later when Talmud books were burned in the same square a few years later. He saw this as divine retribution.<br>Jonah was influenced by Kabbalah and he later returned to his home town of Gerona in Spain where he publically preached his doctrine of ethics and morality, <i>torat ha-musar</i>. He finally settled in Barcelona and became a very popular teacher. He established a large yeshivah in Toledo and died there.<br>He was known as a scholar involved with piety, humility, and ascetism. He wrote on ethics and the bad state of Spanish Jewry which was ignoring the <i>mitzvot</i> especially in matters of sexuality. He inspired public responsibility for each person for his fellow man. He based his ideas and decisions on the <i>halakhah</i> and popular <i>aggadah</i>. He wrote ethical works on social justice and social ethics. He was given credit for writing the <i>Issur ve-Hetter he-Arokh</i> and the laws of the saving of life attached to it.<br>Israel Moses Ta-Shma, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 9, pp. 1085-86; Ephraim Kupfer, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 10, pp. 179-80.</i></small>
When one feeds the pregnant woman or the sick person, we feed that person little by little so that it (the food) will not combine to the prescribed amount of food which is prohibited to eat, therefore we feed him (the equivalent of) two-thirds of a medium (sized) egg and (then) wait as long as the time that is required for the eating of four eggs, and as to the drink, they should examine the sick person himself how much is the liquid so that he can, when it is moved to one side (of his mouth), appear as if he had a mouthful.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">See the Shulḥan Arukh, <i>Oraḥ Ḥayyim</i>, chapter 612, all, above, for the rules that apply in this case.</i>
One should give him to drink (the above amount<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The important element here is the amount of time that passes while eating or drinking on Yom Kippur. "The above amount" refers to the time measurement. It should take longer than the time required to consume four eggs. This applies to both eating and drinking. Food or drink on Yom Kippur must take longer to consume than one would normally take to ingest them. If one must eat on Yom Kippur, then one must eat and drink slowly so that the transgression which results is a minor transgression and not a more serious one. The prohibition of eating and drinking is within a certain time period. A transgression does result, but not as severe a one as would result from eating quickly or even normally. The amount of time one must wait between one drink and the next is at least as long as it takes to drink two <i>revi'it</i>, the amount of one <i>revi'it</i> being one and one-half egg. Therefore the least amount of time one must wait between drinks is the length of time it takes to drink the equivalent of the contents of three (medium) eggs.</i>), and they should wait between one drink and the next one as long as the time that it would take to eat four eggs. And if he (the doctor) estimated that these amounts are not enough for him (the sick person), or if the sick person says thus, or they are doubtful about the matter, we give him food and drink according to his need (immediately).
He who catches ravenous hunger and he (has) a disease that comes from hunger, the symptoms of it are that his eyes are dark and he is not able to see, we feed him until his eyes light up. If there is no permitted food (Kosher<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Kosher food is food which is ritually pure, and which a Jew is permitted to eat. Basically this restricts a Jew to meat from an animal with split-hoofs and which chews its cud, a fish with scales and fins, and certain fowl and locusts, (Leviticus II, Deuteronomy 14). The animals must be killed in a specially prescribed way and be prepared so that all the blood is removed. (See Shulḥan Arukh, <i>Yoreh De'ah</i> I-III, including other relevant laws).</i>) there then we feed him with food that is forbidden (non-Kosher). If there are there two types of forbidden foods, one more strictly prohibited than the other, we feed him the lesser prohibited one first.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">An example of this might be a selection between beef that was not slaughtered according to Jewish law or a cut of beef not permitted and a piece of pork. The pork is more strictly forbidden and therefore of the available choices, the non-Kosher beef would be used instead of the pork.</i><br><small><i>Hagah</i>: If he needs meat and if there is here an animal (a Kosher type) that needs to be slaughtered, and there is also ready non-Kosher meat, see above in chapter  328, paragraph fourteen.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">In the Shulḥan Arukh, <i>Oraḥ Ḥayyim</i>, 328:14 the same situation is discussed as is discussed in 618:9 except in the earlier law the Sabbath is being discussed and not Yom Kippur, but in this case, according to Isserles, the same law applies. A person is sick and for his illness he needs to eat meat. On the Sabbath as on Yom Kippur it is forbidden to slaughter an animal for food under normal circumstances, nor is it permitted to cook food. The question is whether one is able to violate the Sabbath on Yom Kippur to save a life (which is permitted) by killing an animal according to the laws of <i>Kashrut</i> for this person's needs, or is it better to permit the sick person to eat non-Kosher meat that would not require a slaughtering on the Sabbath or Yom Kippur. Which would be more preferable among these two options? The law is that if there was time to do it, that is, if the sick person could wait for the meat, they would slaughter the animal and eventually feed him Kosher meat and not meat from a ritually impure animal. But if the sick person needed the meat immediately and the ritually impure meat was ready, and the slaughtering of a Kosher animal would postpone the sick person from being able to eat too long, then they were permitted to feed him meat from a ritually impure animal in that case to save his life.</i></small>
A sick person who ate on Yom Kippur and recovers to such a degree so that he is able to bless (the food he ate, to say the Grace after the meal<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The Grace after meals, <i>Birkhat ha-Mazon</i>, <span class="rtl">ברכת המזון</span>, is a central part of the home liturgical service. Its obligation is considered biblical from the verse: "Thou shalt eat and be satisfied and bless the Lord thy God for the good land which He has given thee", (Deuteronomy 8:10). It has four parts to it and it should be said only after bread has been eaten. When bread has not been eaten, a shorter version of the Grace is recited.<br>The first blessing, <i>Birkhat ha-Zan</i> praises God for providing food for all His creatures. The second blessing, <i>Birkhat ha-Areẓ</i>, expresses Israel's special thanks for the good land God has given it. It speaks of the redemption from Egypt, the covenant of circumcision and the revelation of the Torah. The third benediction, <i>Boneh Yerushalayim</i> and also <i>Neḥamah</i>, consolation, asks God to have mercy on Israel and to restore the Temple and the Kingdom of David. These blessings also include a plea for God to always sustain and support Israel. This was the core of the Grace after Meals, but after the destruction of Bethar during the Bar Kokhba revolt in 135 C.E. a fourth blessing was added, <i>Ha-tov ve-ha-metiv</i>. It thanks God for His goodness praying that He may fulfill specific desires. This is followed by special petitions which begin with the word <i>Ha-Raḥaman</i>, "May the All-Merciful…" This part of the prayer was once for personal desires but it then became standardized. The number of petitions vary. The Sephardi rite has fifteen while the Ashkenazi only has nine.<br>The Talmud (Ber. 48b) ascribes the origin of each of the benedictions to different Jewish heros and events. The first was originated by Moses when he saw manna fall, the second by Joshua when he conquered Ereẓ Israel, the third by David and Solomon and the fourth by the rabbis at Jabneh although it might actually date back to as early as the reign of Hadrian.<br>The <i>Birkhat ha-Mazon</i>, on Sabbaths and festivals is usually preceded by Psalm 126, which reminds us of Zion and its restoration among our earthly delights. Whenever three or more men have eaten together one of the men begins the Grace by summoning the others, (Ber. 7:1-5), "Gentlemen, let us say Grace", (in the Sephardi rite it is "with your permission"), and the others reply "Blessed be the name of the Lord henceforth and forever." The leader repeats that statement and says, "With your consent (the Sephardim say, "With the permission of heaven"), let us now bless Him of whose food we have eaten." The others respond, Blessed be He whose food we have eaten and through whose goodness we live." This whole introduction is called <i>zimmun</i> (Ber. 45b). The Talmud states that this must be said also by three women who eat together. The <i>zimmun</i> becomes somewhat longer when the number of people together goes to ten, a hundred, a thousand, and ten thousand. Now we insert the word <i>Elohenu</i>, "Our God" in the third line when ten or more eat together. Grace used to be followed by a cup of wine and there was a discussion if this was only when the grace was said with <i>zimmun</i> or also individually, (Shulḥan Arukh, <i>Oraḥ Ḥayyim</i>, 182:1). The custom now is to have the wine only on Sabbaths, festivals, and special occasions.<br>On Sabbaths and festivals special sections are added to the third blessing, <i>Boneh Yerushalayim</i>, these are <i>Reẓeḥ</i> and/or <i>Ya'aleh ve-Yavo</i> and an additional petition is added in series of <i>Ha-Raḥaman</i>. Special <i>Ha-Raḥaman</i> petitions are inserted for New Moons, Rosh HaShanah, Sukkot, Passover, and Shavuot. On Ḥanukkah and Purim the special <i>Al ha-Nissim</i>, "about the Miracles", section is said during the second blessing which is devoted to the thanksgiving.<br>The Grace at a wedding feast is slightly different. The third line of the <i>zimmun</i> is supplemented by "Blessed he our God in whose abode is joy, of whose food we have eaten, and through whose goodness we live" and then the seven wedding benedictions are recited at the end of the Grace. The Grace at the house of a mourner is also changed. The end of the third benediction has a special prayer substituted, the text of the fourth blessing is changed as is the <i>zimmun</i>. At a circumcision ceremony, the wording of the <i>zimmun</i> changes to fit the occasion. The <i>Ha-Raḥaman</i> petitions also allow for passages to be inserted by children, guests or masters of the house.<br>The <i>Birhat ha-Mazon</i> is the only prayer commanded by the Torah but the words were developed by man. Therefore under certain circumstances and for children different, shorter versions have been developed which at least mention the land and Jerusalem. When bread is not eaten another form of Grace is said. It is called <i>Berakhah Aḥronah</i>, a "final benediction" and what is said depends on what is eaten. When one eats of food from the five species of grain; wheat barley, rye, oats, and spelt, wine, or fruits of Ereẓ Israel, a short Grace is said, which consists of one benediction with an insertion for the type of food eaten and for the special nature of the day if it is the Sabbath or a festival. It is called <i>Berakhah Me'ein Shalosh</i>, "a benediction summarizing the three" regular benedictions. For any other food a short benediction called <i>Ve-Lo-Khelum</i>, "nothing" is said. It is also known by its first two words, <i>Bore Nafashot</i>.<br>Editorial Staff, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 7, pp. 838-41.</i>) he has to mention Yom Kippur in “<span dir="ltr">יעלה ויבא״</span><sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ya'aleh ve-Yavo</i>, <span class="rtl">יעלה ויבא</span>, "May our Remembrance rise and come and be accepted before Thee" is a special insertion made to the third blessing of the Grace after the Meal, <i>Birkhat ha-Mazon</i>, (see footnote 137) called <i>Boneh Yerushalayim</i>, which speaks about the restoration of the Temple and the Kingdom of David. It also asks God to have mercy on Israel. The blessing includes a plea for God to sustain and support Israel. The insertion of the <i>Ya'aleh ve-Yavo</i> is made on the festivals and New Moons and the <i>Reẓeh</i> on the Sabbaths. Both are inserted when the Sabbath falls on a festival. Since Yom Kippur is a fast day, there is no special insertion which specifically mentions Yom Kippur in the <i>Birkhat ha-Mazon</i> which is the Grace after Meals, of which there are not to be any on Yom Kippur. According to the Shulḥan Arukh if one must eat on Yom Kippur for reasons of health and then is able to, he must recite the Grace after Meals, and in the third blessing, the <i>Boneh Yerushalayim</i> he must insert the <i>Ya'aleh ve-Yavo</i> prayer which states that it is indeed a holiday, and at the time in the prayer when the specialness of the festival is mentioned, the person must also say "<i>Yom ha-Zikharon ha-Zeh</i>, "This Day of Remembrance" which indicates it is Yom Kippur.</i>” in his Grace after the meal, namely in the benediction called “<span dir="ltr">בונה ירושלים</span><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Boneh Yerushalayim</i>, <span class="rtl">בונה ירושלים</span>, the third blessing in the Grace after Meals; see footnotes 137 and 138.</i>”

Siman 619

<b>“The order (of prayer) on the Night of Yom Kippur” - Containing six paragraphs.</b><br>On the Night of Yom Kippur the custom is that the reader says, “In the court of high, in the court of low (earthly); with the consent of God and with the consent of the congregation, we are permitted to pray together with the transgressors<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">This is the prayer that the reader recites as the services begin on the night of Yom Kippur after the sun goes down marking the beginning of the Day of Atonement. The prayer is said immediately after placing on the <i>talit</i>, the prayer shawl, which is only worn during the day, but exceptionally, also on the night of Yom Kippur.<br>The word "transgressors" at the end of the prayer referred originally to the Marranos, those Jews who chose to convert to Christianity rather than suffer as Jews.</i>”, and it is customary that he say “<i>Kol Nidrei</i>”, (“All the Vows”)<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">The Evening Service (see footnote 144) on the night of Yom Kippur has taken on the name of <i>Kol Nidrei</i>, <span class="rtl">כל נדרי</span>, "All Vows" after the unique Aramaic prayer of the same name that marks the beginning of the Service. The prayer is a supplication for annulment of vows. The congregants pray that all the personal vows, oaths, and obligations that will be made during the coming year should be null and void. This applies to vows made between man and God. The recitation of the <i>Kol Nidrei</i> begins while there is still daylight and is prolonged until the sun sets. It has become the custom to repeat the chant three times so that late comers can be sure and hear it. The prayer relieved anxieties of a person who worried that he might have violated the sanctity of some pledge. The rabbis were concerned with the ease of annulling a vow and put certain restrictions on the procedure.<br>The origin of the <i>Kol Nidrei</i> is not know for sure. It is mentioned in the responsa of Babylonian <i>geonim</i> (see footnote 19) in the eigth century. It was condemned by the <i>geonim</i> of Sura. Some theorize that it originated in Palestine as a Rabhanite practice against the Karaites. Some feel that prayer has mystical origins like other Aramaic prayers which annul curses and oaths which had touched off evil forces in the community. By 1000 C.E. the prayer had been generally accepted by the Pumbedita <i>geonim</i> as a way to invoke pardon, forgiveness and atonement for failing to keep a vow from the previous Day of Atonement to this one. Rabbenu Tam's version changed the wording to read from this Day of Atonement to the next, the wording accepted by most Ashkenazim while most Sephardim except for the oriental and Yemenites, refer to past vows not future ones.<br>Anti-Semites have often used this prayer as evidence that the vow of a Jew was worthless, even though the prayer does not refer to man's vows with his fellow man, only with God.<br>Bathja Bayer, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 10, pp. 1166-68.</i> (and the entire prayer that follows) and afterward he says (the prayer) “<span dir="ltr">שהחינו</span><sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">The prayer <i>Sheheḥayanu</i> is a prayer recited at the beginning of festivals, minor holidays, and at special times which mark a new, significant event and also when acquiring and putting on new clothing. It is a prayer which thanks God for allowing us to live and celebrate a joyous occasion. "Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the Universe, who hast kept us in life, and has preserved us, and enabled us to reach this season."</i>” without a cup (of wine).<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Normally when the <i>Sheheḥayanu</i> (see footnote 142) prayer is recited at a festival, it can be said with a cup of wine, but since Yom Kippur is a fast day, the wine is not permitted.</i><br><small><i>Hagah</i>: And afterwards they say the Evening Prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The Evening Prayer <i>Arvit</i>, <span class="rtl">ערבית</span>, is also referred to as the <i>Ma'ariv</i> Service, which is the word at the beginning and end of the first blessing before the <i>Shema</i>, (see footnote 17 and 173). Originally the <i>Arvit</i> Service was an optional one since there was not an evening Temple sacrifice that corresponded to it as was the case with the <i>Shaḥarit</i> (see footnote 17), <i>Minḥah</i> (see footnote 40) and <i>Musaf</i> (see footnote 166) Service. Traditionally this Service was attributed to Jacob who prayed and Evening Service (Genesis 28:11).<br>The <i>Arvit</i> Service basically consists of a <i>Barekhu</i> which is a call to worship followed by the <i>Shema</i> and its benedictions and the <i>Amidah</i> (see footnote 43). After nightfall Psalm 134 begins the Service. On weekdays the Service begins with Psalms 78:38 and 20:10.<br>The blessings around the <i>Shema</i> are a bit different for the <i>Arvit</i> Service. The theme of the first blessing before the <i>Shema</i> is the change from evening to night and the second blessing is one of thanksgiving for the love shown by God for Israel in revealing his Torah. The blessing which follows the <i>Shema</i> in the <i>Arvit</i> Service is a <i>Ge'ullah</i> prayer which praises God as the Redeemer who redeemed Israel from Egyptian slavery. This is all followed by a special night prayer called the <i>Hashkivenu</i>, "Grant us to lie down in peace", which asks for God's help and protection from various mishaps and dangers that can happen in the mysterious night.<br>There were two versions of the final prayer, a Babylonian and a Palestinian. The Babylonian version is now used on weekdays and it speaks of God "who guards His people Israel forever." The Palestinian version is used on Sabbaths and festivals which is a prayer for peace and Zion; God "who spreads out the tabernacle of peace".<br>In the Ashkenazi rite several scriptural verses beginning with Psalm 89:53, "blessed by the Lord for evermore", are inserted between the <i>Hashkivenu</i> and the <i>Amidah</i>. The Sephardi rite does not have this.<br>The <i>Amidah</i> (see footnote 43) during the <i>Arvit</i> Service is only prayed silently. It is not repeated by the reader as it is in the other Services. The <i>Amidah</i> is preceded by a half reader's <i>Kaddish</i> (see footnote 177) and it is followed by the full reader's <i>Kaddish</i>. The prayer, <i>Aleinu le-Shabbe'aḥ</i> (see footnote 182) concludes the Service.<br>On the evenings of Sabbaths and festivals there are a few changes in the <i>Arvit</i> Service. On the Sabbath it is preceded by a special set of prayers and Psalms which welcome the Sabbath, called <i>Kabbalat Shabbat</i>. The <i>Amidah</i> changes to the special Sabbath <i>Amidah</i> of only seven benedictions. Also a <i>Kiddush</i>, a blessing over wine, is also inserted into the Service. At the conclusion of the Sabbath a special <i>Havdalah</i> (see footnote 226) section is added to the fourth benediction of the <i>Amidah</i> and readings are added to the end of the Service. The <i>Arvit</i> Service usually follows the <i>Minḥah</i> Service immediately after sunset, but it can be recited up until dawn, and under special circumstances, even as late as after twilight.<br>Alexander Carlebach, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 3, pp. 664-66.</i> It is customary to recite “<i>Kol Nidrei</i><sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kol Nidrei</i>, <span class="rtl">כל נדרי</span>; see footnote 141.</i>” while it was still day and to lengthen it with melodies until nightfall, and (“<i>Kol Nidrei</i>”) is said three times, and each time (the cantor) raises his voice “higher” (says it louder) than before, (<span dir="ltr">מהרי״ל</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharil</i>, <span class="rtl">מהרי״ל</span>; see footnote 8.</i> And likewise the reader says the following prayer sentence three times; “And the entire congregation will be forgiven, (etc.)<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">This is a prayer from Numbers 15:26 and 14:19-20 which follows the chanting of the <i>Kol Nidrei</i> (see footnote 141).<br>Ben Zion Bokser. <i>The High Holyday Prayer Book</i>, New York, Hebrew Publishing Company, 1959, p.259.</i>” And the congregation says three times, “And God said I forgave you according to your word”, (<span dir="ltr">מנהגים</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Minhagim</i>, <span class="rtl">מנהגים</span>; see footnote 13.</i> A man must not deviate from the custom of his city even in the melodies or <i>piyyutim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piyyutim</i>, <span class="rtl">פיוטים</span>, is a Hebrew word derived from Greek which means a lyrical composition which was intended to embellish an obligatory prayer in the liturgy, or any other religious service whether communal or private. The word refers to liturgical compositions in Hebrew from the first century of the Common Era until the beginning of the Enlightenment, the <i>Haskalah</i>. Originally <i>piyyutim</i> meant to replace the set versions of prayers, expressing the same basic ideas, mainly on the Sabbath and festivals. When prayers became fixed, <i>piyyutim</i> were inserted into or around a set prayer. Most <i>piyyutim</i> were used to adorn and make beautiful the holy days, but there are many which were written for the Sabbaths, fast days, and even weekdays. There are also <i>piyyutim</i> for weddings, curcumcisions and mourning.<br><i>Piyyutim</i> are characterized from regular prayers by their lofty style and rythm. We know the authors of many <i>piyyutim</i> while others remain anonymous. <i>Piyyutim</i> were produced at one time or another in every land where Jews lived, each area producing its own style. There are <i>Kerovah</i> types of <i>piyyutim</i> which usually are found in the <i>Amidah</i> prayer and <i>Yoẓer piyyutim</i> found in the benediction before and after the <i>Shema</i> in the Morning Service (see footnote 17 and 173). <i>Piyyutim</i> used in the <i>Amidah</i> of <i>Musaf</i> and <i>Arvit</i> for Sabbath and holy days are called <i>shivata</i> because of this <i>Amidah</i> having seven (<i>Shevah</i>) blessings. The Morning Service <i>Amidah</i> for Sabbaths and holy days contains a sanctification prayer, therefore the <i>piyyutim</i> associated there are called <i>Kedushata</i> (sanctification is <i>Kedushah</i> in Hebrew, see footnote 213). Different holy days have special <i>Kerovot piyyutim</i> associated with the characteristic of the holiday. On Yom Kippur the special section of the service describing the Temple Sacrificial Service has many <i>piyyutim</i> associated with the <i>Seder ha-Avodah</i> (see footnote 22). There are many <i>seliḥot piyyutim</i> for the fast days (see footnote 14).<br>Styles and vocabulary of the various <i>piyyutim</i> stretch Hebrew to its fullest in creativity and made the language rich. Many <i>piyyutim</i> are difficult to understand because of the freedom of style and vocabulary that was employed. The first <i>piyyutim</i> only used rhythm but later rhyme also played an important role in the <i>piyyutim</i> especially in Spain. Some have no specific poetical characteristics.<br>Ezra Fleischer, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 13. pp. 573-602.</i> that are said there, (<span dir="ltr">מהרי״ל</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharil</i>, <span class="rtl">מהרי״ל</span>; see footnote 8.</i></small>
On the Night of Yom Kippur and on the next day we say (the blessing), “Blessed be His name whose glorious kingdom is forever and ever” in a loud voice (where normally it is said in a wisper).<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">This is the blessing that is said in response by the congregation to the <i>Barekhu</i>, which is the call to worship made by the reader. In all other services it is said in a wisper, but on Yom Kippur night and during the day it is said outloud by the congregation.<br>The following comment is given by <i>Magen Avraham</i>, (see footnote 33.): 619:8 - "Outloud": Since all year we say it in a wisper because Moses stole it (the response) from the angels, but on Yom Kippur, Israel also resembles the angels, (<i>Tur</i>, <span class="rtl">טור</span>, see footnote 23).</i>
If (Yom Kippur) falls on the Sabbath we say “<span dir="ltr">ויכולו</span><sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">The prayer which begins Va'yekhulu comes from Genesis 2:1-3. It is recited on the Sabbath because it tells the account of God's creation of the seventh day as a day of rest. It is normally recited just before the Sabbath <i>Kiddush</i>, (<i>Kiddush ha-Yom</i>, sanctification of the day; i.e., the Sabbath). There of course is no <i>Kiddush</i> on a fast day such as Yom Kippur, because it is always connected with drinking wine or eating bread.<br>Bokser, <i>op</i>. <i>cit</i>., p. 275.</i>” after the Silent Prayer,<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">For an explanation of the Silent Prayer, the <i>Amidah</i> see footnote 43.</i> and the prayer “<span dir="ltr">תפילת מעין שבע</span><sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tefilat Me'ein Sheva</i>, <span class="rtl">תפילת מעין שבע</span>, is a prayer recited on the Sabbath which is one prayer which summarizes the Sabbath <i>Amidah</i>, containing seven (<i>Sheva</i>, <span class="rtl">שבע</span>) blessings. The substance (<i>Me'ein</i>, <span class="rtl">מעין</span>) of the longer prayer is abbreviated in this short prayer. The ideas of the normal seven benedictions of the Sabbath evening <i>Amidah</i> are included in the prayer.</i>” and conclude (the prayer with the words), “<span dir="ltr">מקדש השבת</span><sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The prayer concludes with the words <i>Mekadesh ha-Shabbat</i>, <span class="rtl">מקדש השבת</span>.</i>”, (“who makes the Sabbath holy”), but do not mention Yom Kippur.<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">There is no special mention in the prayer which states the fact that it is the Day of Atonement, only the fact that it is the Sabbath.<br>There is mention of the fact that it is a high holyday in the <i>Birkhat ha-Mazon</i> if one must eat on Yom Kippur and thus one must say the Grace if he is able. See footnote 138.</i> (We do not say “<span dir="ltr">אבינו מלכנו</span><sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avinu Malkhenu</i>, <span class="rtl">אבינו מלכנו</span>, "Our Father, our King"; see footnote 15.</i>” on the Sabbath, but the rest of the prayers for forgiveness<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Seliḥot</i>, <span class="rtl">סליחות</span>, prayers for forgiveness; see footnote 14.</i> and the supplication prayers<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Taḥanun</i>, <span class="rtl">תחנון</span>; supplication prayers; see footnote 10.</i> one says like on a weekday, (<span dir="ltr">ריב״ש סימן תקיב ומנהגים</span>),<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Isaac ben Sheshet Perfet, chapter 512, and <i>Minhagim</i>, <span class="rtl">ריב״ש סימן תקי״ב דמנהגים</span>.<br><i>R</i>abbi <i>I</i>saac <i>b</i>en <i>Sh</i>eshet Perfet was also known by his acronym <i>Ribash</i>, <span class="rtl">ריב״ש</span>. He lived in Spain from 1326 until 1408. This halakhic authority was born in Barcelona and he studied under Perez ha-Kohen, Ḥasdai b. Judah Crescas and Nissim b. Reuben Gerondi. He moved to Saragossa after he was imprisoned in Barcelona, but his life in his new home was also full of controversy and family tragedy.<br>In Saragossa he tried to abolish certain local customs he did not agree with and he won the anger of many local scholars. He as a result finally moved to Valencia in 1385 where he served as the rabbi. In 1391 there were anti-Jewish riots which forced him to move to North Africa, and he settled in Algiers where he became the communal rabbi and was well respected even though at first his appointment was challenged by Simeon b. Ẓemaḥ Duran (<i>Tashbaẓ</i>, <span class="rtl">תשב״ץ</span>; see footnote 20).<br>Perfet's most important work was his responsa which was published in Constantinople in 1546. His responsa influenced the <i>halakhah</i> after him and Caro used Perfet's decisions extensively in the Shulḥan Arukh. In addition to the vast amount of halakhic material, the responsa also reveal much about the life and customs of the Jews of Spain and North Africa in the fourteenth century. Perfet was the first to discuss the status of the Marranos (Spanish Jews who converted to Christianity so as not to be expelled in 1492) from an halakhic point of view. This became a quite crucial and painful problem for the Jews of Spain and North Africa. Perfet also wrote commentaries on many talmudic tractates and the Pentateuch. He refused to be associated with Kabbalah and even though he knew philosophy, he opposed its study including the works of Maimonides.<br>Hirsch Jacob Zimmels, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 9, pp. 32-33.<br>For <i>Minhagim</i>, <span class="rtl">מנהגים</span>; see footnote 13.</i>).
It is necessary to make one man stand to the right side of the reader and one to his left side (while he is saying these prayers).<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">While the reader is saying these prayers on the night of Yom Kippur he is to be flanked on both sides.</i>
There are people who stand<sup class="footnote-marker">161a</sup><i class="footnote">The following comment is given by <i>Magen Avraham</i>, (see footnote 33.): 619:10 - "Those who stand": This is at the hour of the <i>Arvit</i> Prayer, (see footnote 144), but one who stands throughout the whole night will not be able to pray with devotion during the day (<i>Beit Yosef</i>, <span class="rtl">בית יוסף</span>, see footnote 20). It was written by Moses Mat who lived from 1551 until 1606. He was a Galician rabbi was born in Przemysl. He was a disciple of Solomon Luria. Mat headed the yeshivah in Pesemysl and later lived in Lyuboml and Opatow. He was one of the leading rabbis of Poland and also wrote <i>Taryag Mitzvot</i>, which is a versification of the 613 commandments. He wrote a commentary to the Pentateuch which was actually a supercommentary to the commentary by Rashi. It is customary to spend the night in the synagogue<sup class="footnote-marker">161b</sup><i class="footnote">The following is a comment given by <i>Magen Avraham</i>, (see footnote 33.): 619:11 - "To sleep in the synagogue": <i>Levush</i>, <span class="rtl">לבוש</span>, (see footnote 20a.) wrote that it is better to go to sleep in one's house because he who stays awake at night will sleep during the day, and he will not say with conviction (his prayers). If (he stays awake all night) so as to guard the candles (so the synagogue does not burn down) he should hire a guard instead. Siman 620

<b>“It is a good custom to shorten the Morning Prayer” - Containing one paragraph.</b><br>It is good to shorten the poems and the penitential prayers of the Morning Service so as to speed up the matter so that one can pray the Additional Service<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Musaf</i>, <span class="rtl">מוסף</span>, the Additional Service; is a special section of prayers that is added to the Morning Service on Sabbaths, festivals, and New Moons which corresponds to the additional sacrifice that was made on these days in the Temple. In the Bible (Numbers 28-29) additional offerings are prescribed to be brought on Sabbaths, the three pilgrimage festivals, Sukkot, Pesaḥ, and Shavuot, Rosh HaShanah, Yom Kippur, and Rosh Ḥodesh (New Moons). Talmud tractate <i>Yoma</i> 33a states that this Additional Sacrifice was to be made after the regular Morning Sacrifice. After the Temple was destroyed the <i>Musaf</i> Service found its place after the <i>Shaḥarit</i> (see footnote 17) Service in the prayers on these Sabbaths and festivals. The <i>Musaf</i> Service now comes immediately after the Torah Service, where the Torah and <i>Haftarah</i> (see footnote 170) are read, which follows the Morning Prayers on Sabbaths, festivals, and New Moons. <i>Musaf</i> can be recited anytime during the day, but one who recites it after the seventh hour (1:00 P.M. according to our time system except on Yom Kippur, see footnote 167) is considered a transgressor.<br>The <i>Musaf</i> Service begins with the reader's recitation of the half-<i>Kaddish</i>, or praise of God (see footnote 177), which is followed by the <i>Musaf Amidah</i> (see footnote 43). This <i>Amidah</i> normally consists of seven benedictions, the first and last three being the same as is always said, and the middle benediction known as <i>Kedushat ha-Yom</i>, "Sanctity of the Day". In the case of the <i>Musaf</i> Service the middle benediction has an introductory paragraph followed by a prayer for the restoration of the Temple Service, and it concludes with the section from the Torah which deals with the particular Additional Sacrifice made on that Sabbath or festival.<br>On Rosh HaShanah the <i>Musaf Amidah</i> takes on a unique configuration. It has three central benedictions, thus making a total of nine benedictions in the <i>Amidah</i>. The three benedictions cover the theme of the holy day, <i>malkhuyyot</i> (kingships), <i>zikhronot</i> (remembrances), and <i>shofarot</i> (Ram's Horns, see footnote 221).<br>The <i>Musaf Amidah</i> after being recited silently is repeated outloud by the reader (see footnote 42). On the Sabbath, the <i>Musaf Amidah</i> is made up of twenty-two verses following the Hebrew alphabet backwards, and a description of the <i>Musaf</i> Sacrifice found in Numbers 28:9-10. The <i>Musaf Amidah</i> takes on a slightly different form for each festival. On the Day of Atonement, the <i>Amidah</i> opens with the usual three benedictions. This is followed by the description of the Additional Sacrifices made on Yom Kippur found in Numbers 29:7-8. After this a prayer for the forgiveness of sins is found. The Confession, the <i>Al Ḥet</i> and <i>Ashamnu</i> Prayers (see footnote 45), form the most important part of the <i>Amidah</i> as they do in the other <i>Amidot</i> of Yam Kippur. Various <i>piyyutim</i> (see footnote 149) are added in the reader's repetition of the <i>Musaf Amidah</i> on Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur.<br>Aaron Rothkoff, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 12, pp. 532-34.</i> before the seventh hour (1:00 P.M.).<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">In halakhic literature the daylight hours were divided up into twelve equal parts regardless of how short or long the day was at various times of the year. In rough terms we can think of daylight beginning at 6:00 A.M. and ending at 6:00 P.M. Therefore the first hour of the day, in halakhic terms begins at 6:00 A.M. and ends at 7:00 A.M. We need then only add six to the halakhic hour to get the approximate corresponding time in our system. Therefore the seventh hour for us would be seven plus six, which is thirteen o'clock or, in other words 1:00 P.M.</i>

Siman 621

<b>“The order of the reading of the Torah and of circumcision on Yom Kippur” - Containing six paragraphs.</b><br>We take out (from the ark) two Torah scrolls.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Two Torah scrolls are taken out on the festivals because portions from two separate sections of the Torah are read. The Torahs can be set before hand so that they can be opened to the correct portion without the necessity of rolling the scroll from one portion to the next.</i> In the first Torah six men read from the portion “<span dir="ltr">אחרי מות</span>”, (Leviticus 16:1-18:30) until “and he did as the Lord commanded (Moses)”, (Leviticus 16:34). But if (Yom Kippur) falls on Shabbat, seven (men read from the first Torah), and the <i>Maftir</i><sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maftir</i>, <span class="rtl">מפטיר</span>, means literally "one who concludes". It is the name given to the man who is the last to read in the Torah and he also usually reads the <i>haftarah</i> (see footnote 170), the section of the prophets that corresponds to the Torah reading. <i>Maftir</i> is also the name given to the three or more concluding verses of the regular weekly Torah portion as well as to the final verses read on festivals and public fast days.<br>Editorial Staff, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 11, p. 685.</i> (the last reader) reads from the second (Torah scroll) from the portion, <i>Pinḥas</i>, (Numbers 25:10-30:1), the section “and you shall have on the tenth day of this seventh month”, (Numbers 29:7-11). The <i>Maftir</i> (the <i>Haftarah</i> section from the Prophets<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Haftarah</i>, <span class="rtl">הפטרה</span>, is a portion from the Prophets section of the Bible read after the Torah is read on Sabbaths, festivals, and fast days. On Sabbaths and festivals the <i>haftarah</i> is read during the Morning, <i>Shaḥarit</i> Service (see footnote 17), but on fast days it is read only during the Afternoon, <i>Minḥah</i> Service (see footnote 40). The exception to this is Yom Kippur and <i>Tishah be-Av</i> (see footnote 102) where there is a <i>haftarah</i> after the Torah reading in both the Morning and the Afternoon Service.<br>The Torah in its regular portions is read straight through during the year but such is not the case on festivals and some special Sabbaths. The <i>haftarot</i> are selected in parts from both the Former and Latter Prophets. Only two prophetic books are read in their entirety as <i>haftarot</i>, the Book of Obadiah which has only twenty-one verses and is read after the Torah portion <i>Va-Yishlaḥ</i> (Genesis 32:4-36-43) according to the Sephardi rite, and the Book of Jonah which is the <i>haftarah</i> for the <i>Minḥah</i> Service on Yom Kippur (see the Shulḥan Arukh, <i>Oraḥ Ḥayyim</i> 622:2).<br><i>Haftarot</i> were usually selected so there would be some similarity in content between the Pentateuchal and the Prophetic portions, but often this did not happen and <i>haftarot</i> were chosen because of historical events or because of some special date. Special <i>haftarot</i> are read on special Sabbaths and the <i>haftarah</i> for each festival is based on the nature of the festival.<br>When the custom of reading the <i>haftarah</i> got started is not known for sure, but it is thought that it began during the persecutions of the Antiochus Epiphanes which preceded the Hasmonean revolt. The Torah was not permitted to be read by the Jews during the persecution for it was felt that the reading of it kept the Jews together and gave them a special strength. As a substitute for the Torah reading, sections form the Prophets were chosen that would remind the Jews of the corresponding Torah portion. Appearantly when the ban against reading the Torah was lifted, the practice of reading the <i>haftarah</i> continued. The first mention of the practice of the reading of the <i>haftarah</i> is found in the New Testament. Acts 13:15 states, "after the reading of the law and the prophets". <i>Haftarot</i> are also discussed in the Talmud as to which are to be read at specific times and festivals. In Mishnaic times different communities read different <i>haftarot</i>, and a set order was probably not established until talmudic times. Some <i>haftarot</i> today differ from those recorded in the Talmud, and there are differences in the Sephardi and Ashkenazi rites.<br>The <i>maftir</i>, the one who reads the <i>haftarah</i> also reads the last part of the weekly portion, (i.e., the Torah reader reads it for him). On the Sabbath, after the seventh reader from the Torah, the <i>maftir</i> usually rereads the last three verses of the weekly portion. On festivals and the four special Sabbaths, the <i>maftir</i> reads the special section from the second scroll which is usually a short description of of the festival found in the Torah. Before the <i>haftarah</i> is read (or chanted) the <i>maftir</i> precedes the <i>haftarah</i> with two blessings and after he ends the <i>haftarah</i> he recites three blessings to which a fourth one is added on Sabbaths and festivals. This fourth blessing changes with the nature of the day. The Sabbath <i>haftarah</i> usually has a minimum of twenty-one verses while the festival has at least fifteen verses. Lately it has become the custom for the Bar Mitzvah boy (a man upon reaching the age of thirteen) to chant the <i>haftarah</i> to display his ability with a Hebrew text.<br>Louis Isaac Rabinowitz, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 16, pp. 1342-44.</i>) comes from Isaiah, “and shall say, cast you up, cast you up, prepare the way” until “for the mouth of the Lord has spoken it”, (Isaiah 57:14-58:14).
If there is a circumcision on Yom Kippur;<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">A circumcision must take place on the eighth day after birth, if the baby is healthy, regardless of whether it is the Sabbath, Yom Kippur, or any day of the year. The circumcision takes precedence over anything else.</i> then they circumcize between the (Morning Prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shaḥarit</i>, <span class="rtl">שחרית</span>; see footnote 17.</i> prior to the <i>Keri’at Shema</i> named) “<span dir="ltr">יוצר</span><sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Shema</i>, made up of Deuteronomy 6:4-9; 11:13-21; and Numbers 15:37-41, during the Morning Service is surrounded by two blessings before and one afterwards. (In the Evening Service there are two blessings before and two afterwards.) The Shema and its blessings are called <i>Keri'at Shema</i>, <span class="rtl">קריאת שמע</span>, the Reading of the <i>Shema</i>. It is the basis of a Jew's declaration of One God and his devotion to God. "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is One."<br>The first blessing before the <i>Shema</i> in the mornings is called the "<i>Yoẓer Or</i>", <span class="rtl">יוצר אור</span>, "Who formest light and createst darkness" and it is a prayer of thankgiving for the creation of physical light, the light of day and the daily renewal of creation. (For a further explanation of the Reading of the <i>Shema</i>, see footnote 17).<br>Hertz, <i>op</i>. <i>cit</i>., p. 108.</i>”, “Creator,” and the Additional Service<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Musaf</i>, <span class="rtl">מוסף</span>, Additional Service; see footnote 166.</i> after the reading of the Torah. And after the circumcision we say the prayer, “<span dir="ltr">אשרי</span><sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Ashrei, <span class="rtl">אשרי</span>, means literally "Happy are they". It is the first word and the name of a prayer in the liturgy composed from the Book of Psalms. The prayer is made up of the following: Psalms 84:5, 144:15, 145, and 115:18. The Talmud (Ber. 4b) states that anyone who recites the <i>Ashrei</i> three times a day will be assured of a life in the world to come. Therefore the prayer is read three times a day in the liturgy. It is read twice during the <i>Shaḥarit</i> Service, once in the preliminary psalms, <i>Pesukei de-Zimra</i> (see footnote 17), and once toward the end, and it is read at the beginning of the Afternoon, <i>Minḥah</i> Service (see footnote 40). The <i>Ashrei</i> is also recited before the <i>Seliḥot</i> (see footnote 14), prayers of forgiveness, in the months of Elul and Tishrei. On Yom Kippur the Sephardim recite the <i>Ashrei</i> both at <i>Minḥah</i> and <i>Ne'ilah</i> (see footnote 191) whereas the Ashkenazim only recite it at the <i>Ne'ilah</i> Service.<br>Raphael Posner, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 3, p. 736.</i>” But the custom is to circumcize after the “<span dir="ltr">אשרי</span>”, (<span dir="ltr">מנהגים</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Minhagim</i>, <span class="rtl">מנהגים</span>; see footnote 13.</i> And if the circumcision takes place in a location where it is necessary to leave the synagogue, we do not circumcize him until after the Torah scroll is returned to the ark, and then they return (to the synagogue) and say the (reader’s) <i>Kaddish</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Kaddish</i>, <span class="rtl">קדיש</span>, which literally means "holy" is a doxology, mostly in Aramaic which is recited by a reader with responses made throughout it by the congregation at the close of individual sections and at the conclusion of the whole prayer. There are four principal types of the <i>Kaddish</i>; the whole or complete <i>Kaddish</i>, the half <i>Kaddish</i>, the <i>Kaddish de-Rabbanan</i> (the scholar's <i>Kaddish</i>), and the Mourner's <i>Kaddish</i>.<br>The whole <i>Kaddish</i> basically glorifies God and prays for peace. It is recited by the reader after the <i>Amidah</i> except for the Morning Service when it comes after the prayer <i>U-Va le-Ẓiyyon</i> (see footnote 187). The half <i>Kaddish</i> omits the conclusion of the prayer which consists of the last three blessings. The half <i>Kaddish</i> is recited by the reader between different sections of the service. The <i>Kaddish de-Rabbanan</i> is the whole Kaddish except for a substitution which prays for those who study Torah and teach it. It is recited after communal study, after the reading of the lighting the Sabbath candles in the synagogue (<i>Be-Mah Madlikin</i>, <i>Shabbat</i> 2), after the early Morning Service, and after the song <i>Ein Kh'Elohenu</i> praising God. The Mourner's Kaddish is recited by the close relatives of a deceased person for eleven months following the death and every year on the day which marks the anniversary of that death. It is basically the whole <i>Kaddish</i> with the exception of one line concerning supplications. It is said at certain points of the service, e. g., after the <i>Aleinu</i> (see footnote 182) and may be repeated after the reading of additional psalms.<br>All versions of the <i>Kaddish</i> are said standing facing Jerusalem. The Sephardi form has an additional verse which is not found in the Ashkenazi concerning the coming of the Messiah. At first the <i>Kaddish</i> was not part of the daily synagogue worship but by the geonic period (see footnote 19) it was an established part of the Service and it required ten men (a <i>minyan</i> constituting a congregation) to be recited.<br>The <i>Kaddish</i> did not become a Mourner's prayer until around the thirteenth century as a result of the persecution of German Jews by the Crusades. The prayer is not for the soul of the departed, but rather an expression of the justification of judgment proclaimed by those who have suffered a loss. Man is required to give praise to God even when afflicted by sorrow.<br>Editorial Staff, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 10, pp. 660-62.</i>
We bless the circumcision without a cup (of wine).<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">A cup of wine is used in the circumcision ceremony, but because it is Yom Kippur there was some question as to whether this was permitted or not.</i> (There are those who say that we bless (the circumcision) with a cup (of wine) and we give it to the infant who is 179 circumcized, and this is the custom.<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Children, and therefore certainly infants, are not subject to the laws of fasting on Yom Kippur. The custom, therefore developed that a cup of wine was used in the circumcision ceremony on Yom Kippur. The infant is usually given a small piece of cloth or cotton to suck on which has been dipped in wine. This sanctifies the baby's circumcision according to the Jewish law.</i>)
In the Additional Service<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Musaf</i>, <span class="rtl">מוסף</span>, Additional Service; see footnote 166.</i> the reader recites the order of the <i>Avodah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avodah</i>, <span class="rtl">עבודה</span>, the Sacrificial Service on Yom Kippur; see footnote 22.</i><br><small><i>Hagah</i>: It is customary to fall on their faces, prostrate, as they say the section of the <i>Avodah</i>, “and the priests and the people…” and also to prostrate when saying the <i>Aleinu</i> Prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">The prayer <i>Aleinu Le-Shabbea'aḥ</i>, <span class="rtl">עלינר לשבח</span>, means "It is our duty to praise the Lord of all things." This prayer now is recited at the conclusion to the Morning, Afternoon, and Evening Pryaers, daily and on the Sabbaths and festivals. Originally it introduced the <i>Malkhuyyot</i> (Kingships) section of the Rosh HaShanah <i>Musaf Amidah</i> (see footnote 166). It is also found in the <i>Musaf</i> section of the liturgy for Yom Kippur.<br>The form of the <i>Aleinu</i> is like an early liturgical poem, <i>piyyut</i> (see footnote 149). It has short lines, each having about four words with marked rhythm and parallelism. Some traditions say it was written by Joshua while others give authorship to the men of the Great Assembly during the period of the Second Temple. It probably dates back to the time of the Second Temple because of two reasons. First of all there is no mention of the restoration of the Temple in it, which is unusual for this type of prayer it was written after the Temple was destroyed. Secondly, the prayer demands prostration which was a Temple practice abandoned after the Temple was destroyed except during this prayer on Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur in the Ashkenazi rite. At all other times it is customary to simply bow when reciting the words "we bend the knee…"<br>The main theme of the prayer is the Kingdom of God. God is praised in it for singling out the people of Israel as a nation of God worshippers not idolaters. The second paragraph expresses a hope for the coming of the Kingdom of God when all mankind will recognize the one and only true God, this being a universal ideal.<br>The prayer was censored over the years by the Christians who felt, due to a misunderstanding of the words, that it insulted Christianity even though it pre-dated that religion. Throughout the centuries different parts of the prayer were left out due to outside pressure. The Sephardim for the most part retained the entire original text which has not been restored throughout most of the Ashkenazi rites.<br>Hanoch Avenary, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 2, pp. 556-59.</i> But the reader is forbidden to move from his place at the time of the prayer in order to prosstrate, and one should object to those who do this (prostrate).<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Prostration was part of the Temple Service. It was believed that the <i>Aleinu</i> prayer was part of the Temple service in view of the line in the prayer which states that "we bend the knee and bow down…" (see footnote 182). After the Temple was destroyed it became the custom to only bend one's knee at this above stated line in the <i>Aleinu</i>. In the Ashkenazi rite, the reader would actually prostrate himself when he read this line during the <i>Musaf</i> Service on Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur. This was not done among the Sephardi communities.</i></small>
The order of the confession is; I have sinned, I have transgressed, I have offended, etc.
It is customary to pledge (to vow) charity on Yom Kippur for the dead,<sup class="footnote-marker">183a</sup><i class="footnote">The following comment is given by <i>Turei Zahav</i>, (see footnote 19a): 621:4 - "For the dead": Beit Yosef, <span class="rtl">ב״י</span>, (see footnote 20) cited that there is in a Midrash (stated) that even the dead need atonement and they acquire merit by the (living) giving of charity on their behalf since God examines the hearts (of people) and knows that if they were alive they would have given charity.</i> (and they remember their souls because the dead also have atonement on Yom Kippur), (<span dir="ltr">מרדכי</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i>, <span class="rtl">מרדכי</span>; see footnote 24.</i>

Siman 622

<b>“The order of the Afternoon Service</b><sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Minḥah</i>, <span class="rtl">מנחה</span>, Afternoon Service; see footnote 40.</i> <b>on Yom Kippur” - Containing four paragraphs.</b><br>In the Afternoon Service one says “<span dir="ltr">אשרי</span><sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ashrei</i>, <span class="rtl">אשרי</span>; see footnote 175.</i>”, and “<span dir="ltr">ובא לציון</span><sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote"><i>U-Va Le-Ẓiyyon</i>, <span class="rtl">ובא לציון</span>, is a prayer found near the beginning of the <i>Minḥah</i> Service on Shabbat as well as on festivals. It is of biblical origin coming from Isaiah 59:20-21. It usually follows the <i>Ashrei</i> (see footnote 175). It is also found in additional prayers often recited after the daily <i>Shaḥarit</i>, Morning Service. The prayer speaks of a Redeemer coming to Zion, Jerusalem, and helping Israel who eternally shares in God's covenant.<br>Hertz, <i>op</i>. <i>cit</i>., p. 571.</i>”, but one does not say “<span dir="ltr">ואני תפלתי</span><sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ve'ani Tefilati</i>, <span class="rtl">ואני תפלתי</span>, is a prayer recited on the Sabbath during the <i>Minḥah</i> Service. It closes the prayers immediately preceding the Torah reading done during the Afternoon Sabbath Service. It is only recited on the Sabbath. If a festival occurs on a weekday the prayer is omitted. On Yom Kippur the prayer is omitted even if Yom Kippur falls on the Sabbath because it is not in keeping with the spirit of the Day of Atonement. The prayer is from Psalms 69:14, "And as for me, may my prayer unto Thee, O Lord, be in an acceptable time: O God, in the abundance of Thy lovingkindness, answer me with thy sure salvation."<br><i>ibid</i>., p. 572.</i>” even if it (Yom Kippur) falls on the Sabbath.<br><small><i>Hagah</i> : We are not used to saying “<span dir="ltr">אשרי</span><sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ashrei</i>, <span class="rtl">אשרי</span>; see footnote 175.</i>” and “<span dir="rtl">ובא לציון</span><sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote"><i>U-Va Le-Ẓiyyon</i>, <span class="rtl">ובא לציון</span>; see footnote 187.</i>” before the Afternoon Service, only before the Closing Service, <i>Ne’ilah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ne'ilah</i>, <span class="rtl">נעילה</span>, is a worship service which concludes the prayer service recited on Yom Kippur. The name <i>Ne'ilah</i> was derived from a ritual during the time of the Second Temple. Even though the service is now only recited at the conclusion of the Day of Atonement, it was originally recited on all public fast days including Yom Kippur.<br>The full name of the service is <i>Ne'ilat She'arim</i> which means the "Closing of the Gates". This referred to the daily closing of the Temple gates at night. On Yom Kippur this terminology is symbolically associated with the closing of the heavenly gates which are open until sunset to receive the atonement of a person who truly repents.<br>According to the Talmud, during Temple times <i>Ne'ilah</i> was recited daily one hour before sunset at which time the Temple Gates were closed as there was no evening sacrifice only an Afternoon <i>Minḥah</i> Sacrifice (see footnote 22). On Yom Kippur <i>Ne'ilah</i>, because of the length of the Temple Service and the special rituals involved, could not begin until close to sunset. After the destruction of the Temple and when <i>Ne'ilah</i> became only associated with Yom Kippur, it became the practice for the service to begin close to sunset, before twilight and to end at nightfall.<br>In the third century the <i>Ne'ilah</i> Service consisted of an <i>Amidah</i> of seven benedictions which were parallel to the other <i>Amidot</i> of the day (see footnote 43) and a confession of sins, the <i>Al Ḥet</i> (see footnote 45). The confession of sins though was later replaced by two prayers that are unique to the confession made during the <i>Ne'ilah</i> Service: <i>Attah noten yad le-foshe'im</i>, "Thou stretchest forth Thy hand (in forgiveness) to sinners," and <i>Attah hivdalta enosh</i>, "Thou has distinguished man (from the beast)." These prayers remind man that God eagerly forgives one who is genuinely penitent. There is a basic rabbinic idea that divine judgment is inscribed in the "Book of Life" on Rosh HaShanah, but it is not sealed until the end of the Day of Atonement. Therefore at the end of the <i>Amidah</i> in the <i>Ne'ilah</i> Service the root for the word inscribe, <i>ktv</i>, <span class="rtl">כתב</span>, is replaced by the root for the word seal, <i>ḥtm</i>, <span class="rtl">חתם</span>, when reference is made to the "Book of Life". To help set off the <i>Ne'ilah</i> Service and its uniqueness on Yom Kippur, the <i>Ashrei</i> (see footnote 175) and the <i>U-Va Le-Ẓiyyon Go-el</i> (see footnote 187) prayer which normally come at the beginning of the <i>Minḥah</i> Service on Sabbaths and festivals, come at this time before the <i>Ne'ilah</i> Service.<br>Beautiful liturgical poetry has become associated with the <i>Ne'ilah</i> Service especially prayers of forgiveness, <i>seliḥot</i> (see footnote 14). The central theme of the Service is to give one a final chance and effort to seek forgiveness before the heavenly gates symbolically close at sunset. The Service ends with a feeling of confidence.<br>The <i>Ne'ilah</i> Service contains <i>piyyutim</i> (see footnote 149), an <i>Amidah</i> and a reader's repetition of it, <i>seliḥot</i>, <i>Ashamnu</i> (see footnote 45), <i>Avinu Malkenu</i> (see footnote 15), and the <i>Kaddish</i> (see footnote 177). The entire ritual culminates with a responsive proclamation of the <i>Shema</i> once (see footnote 173, but only the one line "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is One") followed by its response three times, <i>Barukh shem kavod malkhut</i>o <i>le'olam va'ed</i>, "Praised be His glorious Kingdom forever and ever", and <i>Adonai Hu ha-Elohim</i>", "The Lord He is God" (I Kings 18:39) seven times. Finally in the Ashkenazi rite a final single <i>shofar</i> blast (see footnote 221) marks the end of the Day of Atonement, the Sabbath of Sabbaths.<br>Herman Kieval, <i>E</i>. <i>J</i>., v. 12, pp. 943-44.</i>, and so wrote a few of our rabbis, (<span dir="ltr">מרדכי והגהות מיימוני סוף ספר אהבה, וסוף הלכות יו״כ, כל בו ומנהגים</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i> and <i>Hagahot Maimuniyyot</i> at the end of the book <i>Ahavah</i>, Love, (which is the name of the second book of Maimonides' <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, see footnote 59) and the end (of the section) of the Laws of Yom Kippur, and <i>Kol Bo</i> and <i>Minhagim</i>, <span class="rtl">ומנהגים מרדכי והגהות מיימוני סו ״ס״ אהבה וסוף הלכות יו״כ וכל בו</span>.<br>For <i>Mordekhai</i>, <span class="rtl">מרדכי</span>; see footnote 24.<br>For <i>Hagahot</i> Maimuniyyot, הגהות מיימוני; see footnote 27.<br>For <i>Kol Bo</i>, <span class="rtl">כל בו</span>; see footnote 34.<br>For <i>Minhagim</i>, <span class="rtl">מנהגים</span>; see footnote 13.</i> We do not say “<span dir="ltr">אין כאלהינו</span><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><i>En Kh'Elohenu</i>, <span class="rtl">אין כאלהינו</span>, is one of the most popular chants connected with the Jewish liturgy. The Sephardim sing it everyday while the Ashkenazi rite has usually limited its singing to the end of the <i>Musaf</i> Service (see footnote 166) on Sabbaths and festivals shortly before the <i>Aleinu</i> Prayer (see footnote 182). During the geonic period (see footnote 19) it was also chanted during the Evening Services.<br>The prayer expresses God four ways: God, Lord, King, and Savior and that there is none like Him, who is like Him?, we will give thanks to Him, we will bless Him, and proclaim that He is God who our fathers worshipped. Each statement expresses the same thoughts repeated four times, once for each name of God. The first three letters of the first three expressions spells, <span class="rtl">אמן</span>, Amen.<br>Hertz, <i>op</i>. <i>cit</i>., p. 544.</i>”, (“there is none like our God”) on Yom Kippur, (<span dir="ltr">מנהגים</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Minhagim</i>, <span class="rtl">מנהגים</span>; see footnote 13.</i></small>
We take out the Torah scroll and three (men) read from the portion “<span dir="ltr">עריות</span>” (Incest), (Leviticus 18:1-21) until the end of the portion and the third (man reads) the <i>Maftir</i> (<i>Haftarah</i>) from the Book of Jonah<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maftir</i>, <span class="rtl">מפטיר</span>, and <i>Haftarah</i>, <span class="rtl">הפטרה</span>;
